warning: variable is declared but never referenced: uarg
warning: variable is declared but never referenced: funcs
warning: undeclared identifier: uarg
line > 80 characters
indent by spaces instead of tabs
line > 80 characters
line > 80 characters
These asserts don't have a message like others in this file, is that intended?

Yeah, I was following the precedent established by the waterfall() func. But other funcs (like forEachParallel) don't follow this convention. Will add messages to asserts that were introduced by me in this commit.
Why is '--stdout' needed here?
So that console.log()'s show up in the stdout. This should be the default, IMHO.
Why is mocha relevant here?

Because that's what the async module by caolan uses now. It was our original intention to copy his tests and use them to test our implementation of async functions (like waterfall and tryEach). However, he moved on from node-tap to mocha. Instead of adding a dependency on Mocha, I transliterated his tests from mocha to tap. This comment is here to inform future readers of the code that this happened, and that we may wish to some day depend on mocha instead which would be a much bigger migration-type change that is out of the scope of this ticket.
nit: it seems this file uses a blank line to separate each test function.
Because we want to be a drop-in replacement for node-async. That's what async does, so we have to do it too. This compatibility is handled in waterfall_impl on lines 540-544.

> Because we want to be a drop-in replacement for node-async. 

That's not mentioned in the ticket, in the documentation or in the implementation, so it's a bit difficult to understand the tradeoffs.

Am I correct to guess that this is needed for the work being done to implemented vminfod?

Well, it is mentioned at the very top of this file in the comment (but it's not visible in diff-mode). According to dap, we have customers that like the visibility offered by vasync, but that have existing async-based code-bases that they would rather not change (they want a drop-in replacement). I haven't looped myself into vminfod updates, so I am not sure.

> Well, it is mentioned at the very top of this file in the comment (but it's not visible in diff-mode).

Ah, that's what I was missing, thank you for pointing that out!
Supporting passing more than one "result" to the callback seems inconsistent with e.g vasync.pipeline. Is the divergence intended? What is the use case for this?
Same as above, that's what node-async expects so we have to do it too.

Should that be "Should not have been called" or "Should not be called"?

Also, I'm not familiar with tap, but do we know that it doesn't swallow uncaught errors silently? Otherwise a "test.fail()" in lieu of the "assert" might be a better solution.

Yeah, this is a consequence of trying to stick to caolan's tests. Here is the exact line:

https://github.com/caolan/async/blob/master/mocha_test/tryEach.js#L77

So, I wouldn't fix this until caolan fixes it. Also, we use assert.fail because that's what caolan did, but if that's not adequate, I'll make it test.fail() [will test this on node-tap].
warning: variable is declared but never referenced: uarg
warning: variable is declared but never referenced: funcs
line > 80 characters
indent by spaces instead of tabs
line > 80 characters
There's a convention in this repo to quote keys inside object literals.  It's not a big deal, but we do already do this uniformly, so it would be nice to preserve.
Yeah, will quote all the keys. Out of curiosity, though: why do we quote the keys? Syntax highlighting?
One reason would be consistency, given that some keys will require quoting (e.g., when they're not otherwise valid identifiers).
Sounds good.
Should we assert on the type of "opts" first? That is, should we assert it's an object?
Yep, oversight on my part.
Wasn't a return value passed to the "waterfall"'s callback even if "funcs.length === 0" before this change?

Yeah, and that was a bug on our side. It's just that caolan's waterfall tests don't check for that value, so we never caught it. And apparently nobody ever tried to access or use that value in practice (thankfully).

> And apparently nobody ever tried to access or use that value in practice (thankfully)

How did we check that? In other words, would that change be considered a breaking change and mandate a major version bump?

Well, we never received any complaints from customers, which leads us to speculate that nobody has run into this. Having consulted with dap, it seems that we have 2 options. (1) bump the major version and don't think about it. Or (2) bump a micro version, and if anybody breaks, we can mark that version un-installable, and bump a major. (2) has the same effect as (1), except that (a) it helps us discover who (if anyone) has been misusing the waterfall call and (b) allows people to use the new features 'for free' if nobody reports any issues. Dap doesn't feel strongly about either variant. I myself prefer (2) because I am curious to see who (if anyone) is misusing vasync, and because it seems unlikely to be a problem. But I do understand that (2) comes with some uncertainty. If you feel very strongly about (1), we can do that instead.

I have a preference for 1) because that seems to be a smoother path for our customers, and that's what I tend to prioritize. But I don't have strong feelings either way, I wanted to make sure we were aware of the tradeoffs.
Ok, a major bump seems like the safest option. Thanks for the thorough review!
Why not just set "args" to an empty array at line @576 instead?

Because, in `waterfall` the tasks/funcs can call the callback with an arbitrary number of args. The 'excess' args that are passed to this callback get passed to the sequentially next function in the funcs/tasks array that we call `waterfall` on (in here, opts.funcs). So, we may have >= 2 args. Setting to an empty array would cause us to 'drop' all the args, which would violate the waterfall interface. Relevant documentation: https://caolan.github.io/async/docs.html#waterfall
Oh, I see. Yes, this arrangement of branches is definitely easier to understand, than what's currently here. Will change this. Thanks for point this possibility out.

So, I tried out this change, and the code doesn't quite work the way we thought it did (tests were failing). tryEach does 'forward' its results (like waterfall), but only once to the final callback (because tryEach stops on success). So we need the array-slice and can't do `args = []`. As the special case here, we need it because unlike pipeline and waterfall, tryEach's given `funcs[]` each take a single argument (the callback). Which is why we pass `next` to `nfunc`. The code would have to stay as it is, to support this difference in interaction between tryEach and the other two. Sorry I missed this nuance the first time around.

OK, that sounds good to me, thank you for the clarification, and sorry for the confusion!

It might be helpful to make that more explicit with comments, so that we don't scratch our heads again in a few months when looking at this code :)
This seems to no longer be true.  Can we put these tests into a separate file?  (Can we use the same pattern in that new file?)

Sure. Although, for the tryEach test to be 'unchanged from the source' we would have to support mocha tests (which *looks* like it would require a test-procedure more sophisticated than `npm test` (probably `make test`) --- but correct me if I'm wrong). Also, the 'upstream' waterfall tests in async use mocha now as well. Should we migrate our compat-tests to that? (I checked those out a while ago and the tests look identical --- just cosmetic differences like different members and method calls, etc). 

The tap to mocha conversion in node-async (for waterfall):
https://github.com/caolan/async/commit/a201c6e46e5adad8de3dc21a3e5ed998dfa4d9e9#diff-b5062926fd0a997a22efca5cb0222c69

Thanks.  It sounds like it's not worth preserving the existing tryEach tests verbatim.  That's fine, but I still think it's helpful for them to be in a separate file, with some explanation of where they came from.  (Are they new tests?  Ported from the mocha tests?)

Given that the waterfall test changes are cosmetic, I don't think it's worth converting them here to support mocha either.
The tryEach tests are ported from the mocha tests (there is a 1:1 correspondence, I've even preserved caolan's original typos). I'll go ahead and split this file into two.

Typo "The the".
"From the callback-user's perspective gets", is there a word missing?
The comment above states "the `results` variable that gets passed to the callback is never undefined", but here it seems that it is the case. Am I missing something?
Ah, that comment was written before it became clear we needed to be a full drop-in replacement. Will update it.

It also doesn't provide a first argument.

Might it be easier to just say something like: `tryEach` invokes each of the asynchronous functions in `funcs` serially, with no argument other than the callback, until one of them does not produce an error.  At the end, the final `callback` is invoked with the error and/or results provided by the last function that was called (which would be either the results from the call that succeeded, if any did, or the error from the last function in the list).

Maybe that's not easier...
extra "-" (or line wrap, but I think "--" is sufficient for an em dash)
"propagated"
Good catch.
Right. Three is for LaTeX, not markdown.
I'll try to work this in there.
"one"?
Sure. I just find it easier to skim docs when values are in numeric form. But "one" is more proper.
extra space
Fixing. Also the other em-dash above.

Thanks for adding this file.

The v2.0.0 entry needs to describe the breaking change, including how people can know whether their code is affected and how to fix their code.  I probably should have referred you to node-moray's, which has two examples of this (https://github.com/joyent/node-moray/blob/791780c7c78c5c0d63b1b75f4e97ea15153c6a0d/CHANGES.md).

I think it would be useful to have at least one catch-all entry for "v1 and earlier", even if it basically just says that these versions predate tracking changes in CHANGES.md (similar to the one in node-moray).
Thanks, will add description, and the 'v1 and earlier' entry. Thanks for the link.
provided?
Yeah, sorry.
"final callback"?
Yep, final callback, not interstitial callbacks.
I don't think I understand who the callback user is.  Is that the implementor of the final callback?
That is the implementor of the final callback.
I don't think you need to bother even saying this (but it's also fine).
Probably drop the "," here.
This isn't a complete sentence.

Do you mean that, before this change, waterfall's terminating callback was called with two parameters, the second being the "status-object", only when passing it an empty array of function? That seems surprising.

Yep. Here is the code that does this: https://github.com/joyent/node-vasync/blob/master/lib/vasync.js#L557

Note that when passing a non-empty array, the terminating callback does not get passed a status object. Which happens here: https://github.com/joyent/node-vasync/blob/master/lib/vasync.js#L590

It is certainly surprising that nobody has noticed this slight divergence in behavior between async and vasync.
It seems that this whole paragraph would be clearer by using code examples, but I'd be fine with this being improved in a future change.
Yeah, this is not the most eloquent paragraph I've ever written; I'll see what I can do to make it clearer.

Is --stdout a tap command line option? Does it actually exist?

➜  node-vasync git:(master) ✗ ./node_modules/.bin/tap --help 2>&1 | grep -2 stdout
➜  node-vasync git:(master) ✗ ./node_modules/.bin/tap --version                   
0.4.13
➜  node-vasync git:(master) ✗
It certainly does. And I think it was introduced as part of this ticket: https://github.com/tapjs/node-tap/issues/3
